Title.evidence: BACKGROUND: There is no consensus on optimal management of pilonidal disease.

Trial_Design.evidence: DESIGN: Observational cohort study with nested mixed-methods case study.

Participants.evidence: PARTICIPANTS: Patients aged > 16 years referred for elective surgical treatment of pilonidal disease.

Objective.evidence: OBJECTIVES: A prospective cohort study to determine: • disease severity and intervention relationship • most valued outcomes and treatment preference by patients • recommendations for policy and future research.

Method_Outcome.evidence: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Pain postoperative days 1 and 7, time to healing and return to normal activities, complications, recurrence.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Cohort study: Over half of patients (60%; N = 667) had a major procedure.

Result_Outcome.evidence: For these procedures, pain was greater on day 1 and day 7 (mean difference day 1 pain 1.58 points, 95% confidence interval 1.14 to 2.01 points, n = 536; mean difference day 7 pain 1.53 points, 95% confidence interval 1.12 to 1.95 points, n = 512).

Harms.evidence: There were higher complication rates (adjusted risk difference 17.5%, 95% confidence interval 9.1 to 25.9%, n = 579), lower recurrence (adjusted risk difference -10.1%, 95% confidence interval -18.1 to -2.1%, n = 575).

Trial_Registration.evidence: TRIAL REGISTRATION: This trial is registered as ISRCTN95551898.

Funding.evidence: FUNDING: This award was funded by the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme (NIHR award ref: 17/17/02).
